title: 111_s590
content: The Defense Communities Assistance Act of 2009 aims to assist local communities affected by base closures, realignments, and military growth initiatives by providing federal assistance to implement Department of Defense programs and convey property at military installations for construction purposes. Section 2869(a)(3) of title 10, United States Code, is amended to remove time limitations on the authority to purchase municipal services for military installations in the United States. The Secretary concerned may enter into a contract for municipal services for military installations in the US from local governmental units in the area. Services include refuse collection, disposal, library, and recreation services. The Secretary concerned may enter into a contract for municipal services for military installations in the US from local governmental units in the area. Services include refuse collection, disposal, library, recreation, facility maintenance, repair, and utilities. Competitive procedures may be waived for contracts not exceeding 5 years if the price is fair, reasonable, represents the least cost, and considers small business concerns. The determination under paragraph (2) must describe the availability, benefits, and drawbacks of alternative sources and show that performance by the county or municipal government will not increase costs to the Federal Government. Delegation of this authority is limited to a Deputy Assistant Secretary for Installations and Environment or an equivalent official. Congressional notification is required before entering into a contract for procurement of services. The Secretary must notify Congress before entering into a contract for municipal services procurement, with a 14-day waiting period. The notification should include a business case summary and plans to minimize adverse impacts on Department of Defense civilian employees. The Secretary of Defense will issue guidance for implementing this section. Section 325(f) of the Ronald W. Reagan National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2005 is extended to September 30, 2020. Section 2701(d)(1) of title 10, United States Code, is amended to include property transfers before or after remediation without conditioning funding based on a State's enforcement authority. SEC. 6. INDEMNIFICATION OF TRANSFEREES OF CLOSING DEFENSE PROPERTIES. Amends Section 330(a)(1) of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1993 to provide indemnification for costs, expenses, or fees related to personal injury, environmental remediation, or property damage resulting from hazardous substances. SEC. 7. REQUIREMENT FOR NO-COST ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT CONVEYANCES. Repeal of certain requirements from the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2002 and revival of provisions from the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990. The Secretary of Defense must implement regulations within 60 days to ensure surplus real and personal property transfers by military departments. The Secretary of Defense must implement regulations to transfer surplus military property without consideration to local authorities for economic development. A report on economic development conveyances, job creation, and community reinvestment must be submitted to Congress within 180 days.
